body: @fjy could you point me to the one you consider "the original HLL sketch" please?

@jihoonson I built this function on RealtimePlumber, and probably not fit for Appenderator, so I remove dedupField from all Appenderator code for now, and maybe add dedup support for Appenderator later.

In  RealtimePlumber.  `sink` and interval are bound, dedup can be easily done inside a sink.

But it is more complex in  Appenderator, different sink may share same interval, like 
1. targetPartitionSize in IndexTask
2  late events are allowed to build a new sink

for senior 2, I think there isn't a good way to do global dedup,  so maybe it's better to do dedup case by case and add dedup support in Appenderator later
@gianm thanks!
@b-slim no problem! Are you ok with merging this?

@kaijianding thanks. I have a follow-up question. The motivation of this PR is to remove duplicate rows, but the implementation checks only one column which looks not enough to check duplication. Is this useful only when there is a unique column like primary key?
LGTM

Hi @sanastas, thank you for this work. It looks not ready for merging yet, but I'll take a look. 

Before that, I wonder what's your plan about opening the source code of Oak you noted [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5698#issuecomment-384328912). Also which license are you thinking to use?
Does it make sense to backport to 0.12.1 even though this bug existed even before 0.12.0?
I think probably not, since it's not a regression and we already started the RC train. Although if we end up doing an rc2 for some other reason, maybe we could include this one too, since why not.

@sanastas how about `indexer.processRowValsToUnsortedEncodedKeyComponent()`? this is called in `index.toTimeAndDims();` the StringDimensionIndexer uses on-heap to hold dictionary data, do you think it's worth moving the dictionary to off-heap? If it is high cardinality, it may cause frequent young gc

I have a similar problem just now. I tried to change the Kafka topic of a datasource by resubmitting the changed supervisor to overlord. Now all tasks fail, in the logs I see it complaining about the Kafka offsets not matching.
I'm not sure how I can achieve this, looking into manually removing the datasource entry from the mysql DB now.
@pantaoran Did you tried to reset the offsets ? `POST /druid/indexer/v1/supervisor/<supervisorId>/reset`

Hi @kaijianding ,
You have a valid point about this translation to TimeAndDims. We saw the existence of this dictionary, however we believe it is better to postpone dealing with this translation after we merge Oak to Druid. As you can see already now the pool request is big and there is no need to make it any bigger. 
Currently we concentrate on the keys that are TimeAndDims, and their creation remains as it was before Oak.
Generally it should be beneficial to take the dictionary off-heap, however we postpone this and currently disregard this translation.

I totally forgot that this API existed! It actually seems perfectly suited to solve my problem.
I have another datasource with the same problem, and after this call its tasks now succeed again.
Thanks!
@sanastas I see. hope this pr be merged soon
Merging this without Travis passing, since the changes are just to the docs, and they can't possibly affect tests passing.

Actually, before we commit this -- @stuartmclean could you please fill out the project CLA? It's at http://druid.io/community/cla.html. Let us know when you've finished.

This doesn't bring in the need for the java Unlimited strength Cryptography Extension does it?
Awesome! https://github.com/lz4/lz4-java/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Apr+author%3Adrcrallen

@drcrallen it doesn't need it. From the linked doc above,

> Server-side encryption is about data encryption at rest—that is, Amazon S3 encrypts your data at the object level as it writes it to disks in its data centers and decrypts it for you when you access it. As long as you authenticate your request and you have access permissions, there is no difference in the way you access encrypted or unencrypted objects.

BTW, a recent change (#5583) merged into master includes a change of the signature of HadoopTuningConfig which makes merging this PR failed. Would you update this PR?
If these are becoming more common, would it make sense to have a Dropwizard compatible metrics registry interface so we don't have to code our own on-heap metrics collectors?
@drcrallen I've not used Dropwizard before, do you have an example implementation in mind?

http://metrics.dropwizard.io/4.0.0/manual/core.html

Has a bunch of examples. Such a metrics interface is common among a few other projects.

https://beam.apache.org/documentation/sdks/javadoc/2.4.0/org/apache/beam/sdk/metrics/Metrics.html

https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/monitoring.html#metrics
Thanks, Dropwizard looks useful, I'll check it out
May be dirty cache on my side, checking

the answer of this question is
it has two conf folders: 'conf' and 'conf-quickstart'
@drcrallen i believe drop-wizard still uses onheap space, but i agree maybe it is a good idea to use a common library to do something like moving average or histograms

@b-slim agreed, that's my main concern. That we would need to maintain a metrics collection library (histograms / moving averages / rate calculators) when there are already good and widely used ones out there.

Hmm, probably better to initialize `maxBytesInMemory` in the constructor of `AppenderatorImpl` using `TuningConfigs.getMaxBytesInMemoryOrDefault()` and use it all places to reduce this kind of mistakes?

Initially it was `tuningConfig.getMaxBytesInMemory() == -1`, but got changed to `tuningConfig.getMaxBytesInMemory() > 0`, which lead to ignoring this if it's 0.  Perhaps we need this change at other places where `== -1` was changed `>0`.

I meant, if we initialize `maxBytesInMemory` to a something infinite (like Long.MAX_VALUE) in case when it is set to `-1`, I think it's easier to avoid this kind of mistakes.

BTW, I found another one: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/incremental/OnheapIncrementalIndex.java#L173.

@drcrallen Changed this to use Dropwizard metrics Meter objects to collect row stats (instead of FireDepartmentMetrics)

Dropwizard has a dependency on slf4j 1.7.25 (https://github.com/dropwizard/metrics/blob/4.1-development/pom.xml), Druid uses 1.7.12, but there shouldn't be any compatibility issues between those versions (https://www.slf4j.org/compatibility.html).

Reverting this, the following code passes in an offHeap backed map from MapDb, so we'd inadvertently be copying all of its data onHeap when creating the BiMap

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/5929066dfba96c918f14e26b629534f53de0f9cd/extensions-core/lookups-cached-global/src/main/java/io/druid/query/lookup/NamespaceLookupExtractorFactory.java#L216

@michas2 thanks for the contribution! The CI failure looks not related to this change. I restarted it.

Would you add a unit test to `StorageLocationTest` to avoid such mistakes in the future?

I did some measurements of accuracy:
https://datasketches.github.io/docs/HLL/HllSketchVsDruidHyperLogLogCollector.html

Datasketches HLL is substantially more accurate for the same size. Druid HyperLogLogCollector shows significant bias in low counts and a glitch around 5000 counts.

Our sketch can be configured from k=16 to k=2M, and can merge sketches with different k.

If one wants to have a very crude estimate (order-of-magnitude cardinality), our sketch can do this using 48 bytes (k=16).

Besides, we have Hive and Pig plugins so that sketches can be prepared in batch mode on Hadoop and ingested into Druid.

I suspect that our HLL sketch is faster, but I didn't do specific time measurements. The accuracy test runs about 8 to 9 times faster, but this only involves HyperLogLogCollector.add() method (no merging).
I'm working on this and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5729.
